title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as Corporation, Red Rock, Red Rock Map, and Secretary. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to enhance Red Rock. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a master-planned community, including 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock. The Corporation owns high-ground lands near Red Rock in Las Vegas Valley and proposes that the United States acquire them to preserve and expand Red Rock. This Act aims to exchange lands to protect and expand Red Rock's boundaries. To protect and expand Red Rock, the Corporation proposes the acquisition of high-ground lands near the area. This aligns with the Bureau of Land Management's plans and fulfills the goals of relevant conservation acts. The Corporation proposes a Red Rock land exchange. The Corporation offers to convey approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States. The Secretary will accept the offer and make conveyances of Federal lands to the Corporation and Clark County, Nevada. The Federal property to be conveyed shall be done simultaneously. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map on file for public inspection. Conditions include hazardous materials removal and a survey requirement within 90 days of the offer. The Corporation must provide a survey of the boundary between the parcels to be conveyed. The lands transferred to Clark County must be used as a public park or trail system, and if used inconsistently, they will revert to the United States. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as "Flood Control Detention Basin Lands" as part of Red Rock, excluding those used for the Corps of Engineers R-4 Detention Basin. Acquired lands will also be administered as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 and other laws require the creation of new maps showing the boundaries of Red Rock. A conforming amendment includes additional areas in the conservation area. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 and other laws require new maps showing Red Rock boundaries, with a conforming amendment adding areas to the conservation area. General provisions are outlined in Section 6. The Secretary must review an appraisal for a land exchange in Las Vegas and any difference in values will be reimbursed. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights, and parties will succeed to rights and obligations. Parties can agree to correct technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired or already owned by the United States within the Red Rock National Conservation Area boundaries, subject to valid existing rights. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
